verses.text: The second lot came out for Simeon, for the tribe of the sons of Simeon according to their clans. Their inheritance was inside the inheritance of the sons of Judah.
verses.comment: Simeon's territory is within Judah's, indicating close relationship between the tribes.

verses.text: They had for their inheritance Beersheba (or Sheba), Moladah,
verses.comment: Beersheba also called Sheba, per textual variant.

verses.text: Hazar Shual, Balah, Ezem,
verses.comment: Cities listed are southern, in the Negev.

verses.text: Eltolad, Bethul, Hormah,
verses.comment: Hormah was a notable ruin from earlier battles.

verses.text: Ziklag, Beth Marcaboth, Hazar Susah,
verses.comment: Ziklag became famous in David’s time.

verses.text: Beth Lebaoth, and Sharuhen—thirteen cities with their villages;
verses.comment: Total of 13 cities listed in this verse.

verses.text: Ain, Rimmon, Ether, and Ashan—four cities with their villages;
verses.comment: Four more cities, southern Judah region.

verses.text: and all the villages which are around these cities as far as Baalath Beer, Ramah of the Negev. This is the inheritance of the tribe of the sons of Simeon according to their clans.
verses.comment: Area described extends to Baalath Beer and Ramah in the Negev.

verses.text: The inheritance of the sons of Simeon was out of the portion of the sons of Judah, because the portion of the sons of Judah was too large for them. So the sons of Simeon got their inheritance inside Judah’s inheritance.
verses.comment: Simeon’s territory reduced as prophecy in Gen. 49:7 (Jacob’s blessing/curse).

verses.text: The third lot came up for Zebulun according to their clans. The territory of their inheritance was as far as Sarid.
verses.comment: Sarid marks the boundary—northern Israel.

verses.text: Their border went up westward to Maralah, touched Dabbesheth, and reached to the brook that is east of Jokneam.
verses.comment: The Jokneam brook forms a significant boundary.

verses.text: It turned from Sarid eastward toward the sunrise to the border of Chisloth Tabor, went out to Daberath, and went up to Japhia.
verses.comment: Eastern travel toward Chisloth Tabor and nearby towns.

verses.text: From there it passed eastward to Gath Hepher, to Eth Kazin, went out to Rimmon, and turned toward Neah.
verses.comment: Gath Hepher—Jonah’s hometown (2 Kgs. 14:25).

verses.text: The border went around on the north to Hannathon, and ended at the Valley of Iphtah El.
verses.comment: Northern boundary of Zebulun’s land.

verses.text: Kattath, Nahalal, Shimron, Idalah, and Bethlehem—twelve cities with their villages.
verses.comment: Bethlehem here is in Zebulun, not Judah (distinct from birthplace of Jesus).

verses.text: This is the inheritance of the sons of Zebulun according to their clans, these cities with their villages.
The fourth lot came out for Issachar, for the sons of Issachar according to their clans.
verses.comment: Issachar’s inheritance now specified.

verses.text: Their territory included Jezreel, Chesulloth, Shunem,
verses.comment: Jezreel—later site of notable battles.

verses.text: Hapharaim, Shion, Anaharath,
Rabbith, Kishion, Ebez,
Remeth, En Gannim, En Haddah, and Beth Pazzez.
The border reached to Tabor, Shahazumah, and Beth Shemesh, and ended at the Jordan—sixteen cities with their villages.
verses.comment: Tabor is mountain, also becomes significant later (Judg. 4:6).

verses.text: This is the inheritance of the tribe of the sons of Issachar according to their clans, the cities with their villages.
The fifth lot came out for the tribe of the sons of Asher according to their clans.
Their territory included Helkath, Hali, Beten, Achshaph,
Allammelech, Amad, and Mishal. It reached to Carmel on the west, and to Shihor Libnath.
verses.comment: Carmel, known for Elijah; Shihor Libnath likely a stream.

verses.text: It turned eastward to Beth Dagon, and reached to Zebulun and to the Valley of Iphtah El northward to Beth Emek and Neiel. Then it went north to Kabul,
verses.comment: Kabul was the district given to Hiram by Solomon (1 Kgs. 9:13).

verses.text: Ebron, Rehob, Hammon, and Kanah, as far as Great Sidon.
verses.comment: Sidon is Phoenician coastal city, outside Israel proper.

verses.text: Then the border turned to Ramah, reaching to the fortified city of Tyre; then the border turned to Hosah, and ended at the sea by the region of Achzib.
verses.comment: Tyre another coastal Phoenician city.

verses.text: Ummah, Aphek, and Rehob—twenty-two cities with their villages.
This is the inheritance of the tribe of the sons of Asher according to their clans, these cities with their villages.
The sixth lot came out for the sons of Naphtali, for the sons of Naphtali according to their clans.
Their border ran from Heleph, from the oak in Zaanannim, Adami Nekeb, and Jabneel, as far as Lakkum, and ended at the Jordan.
verses.comment: Zaanannim referenced in Judg. 4:11—Jael’s home.

verses.text: Then the border turns westward to Aznoth Tabor, goes out from there to Hukkok, reaches to Zebulun on the south, to Asher on the west, and to Judah at the Jordan toward the sunrise.
verses.comment: Describes intersection of tribal territories.

verses.text: The fortified cities are Ziddim, Zer, Hammath, Rakkath, Chinnereth,
verses.comment: Chinnereth is Sea of Galilee; Hammath perhaps near Tiberias.

verses.text: Adamath, Ramah, Hazor,
verses.comment: Hazor — major northern city conquered by Israel.

verses.text: Kedesh, Edrei, En Hazor,
verses.comment: Kedesh — city of refuge.

verses.text: Iron, Migdal El, Horem, Beth Anath, and Beth Shemesh—nineteen cities with their villages.
This is the inheritance of the tribe of the sons of Naphtali according to their clans, the cities with their villages.
The seventh lot came out for the tribe of the sons of Dan according to their clans.
The territory of their inheritance included Zorah, Eshtaol, Ir Shemesh,
verses.comment: Zorah and Eshtaol — home of Samson (Judg. 13:2).

verses.text: Shaalabbin, Aijalon, Ithlah,
verses.comment: Aijalon — site of Joshua’s battle (Josh. 10:12).

verses.text: Elon, Timnah, Ekron,
verses.comment: Timnah — place of Samson’s Philistine wife (Judg. 14:1).

verses.text: Eltekeh, Gibbethon, Baalath,
Jehud, Bene Berak, Gath Rimmon,
Me Jarkon, and Rakkon, with the territory near Joppa.
verses.comment: Joppa — main port city for Israel.

verses.text: But the territory of the sons of Dan was too small for them. So the sons of Dan went up and fought against Leshem, and took it and struck it with the sword, and took possession of it and lived in it, and they called Leshem, Dan, after the name of their father Dan.
verses.comment: Dan’s migration and conquest explained in more detail in Judg. 18.

verses.text: This is the inheritance of the tribe of the sons of Dan according to their clans, these cities with their villages.
When they had finished distributing the land for inheritance by its borders, the sons of Israel gave an inheritance among them to Joshua son of Nun.
verses.comment: Joshua’s faithfulness rewarded by his own inheritance.

verses.text: By the command of the Lord they gave him the city which he asked for, Timnath Serah in the hill country of Ephraim. He built the city and lived in it.
verses.comment: Timnath Serah became Joshua’s burial site (Judg. 2:9).

verses.text: These are the inheritances which Eleazar the priest, Joshua son of Nun, and the heads of the families of the tribes of the sons of Israel distributed by lot at Shiloh before the Lord, at the entrance of the tent of meeting. So they finished dividing the land.
verses.comment: Final administrative summary; the land division completed at Shiloh before the Lord’s presence.
